Factionalism and an increase in instability within the institutions of government and the military could lead to internal conflicts.

While it is certain that rival groups will engage in lethal hostilities there is little advantage to be gained by one group seeking to cleanse areas by direct killing. Not only is the general population more armed than might be typical, but factional acts of this nature would tend to drive support for other opposing groups while also removing potential workforces in the economy. That said, it is not out of the question that regional and global adjustments may pressure some group or coalition of groups to attempt hegemony.

Congo is sliding into another civil war and militant Islamic groups have risen in Africa, increasing the probability a mass causality attack. MTM called for jihadist to join the fight in the Congo in late 2017 and some reports link the ADF to al Qaeda. The confidence is only a 40% due to the 1,000 fatality standard.

Tensions and political unstability increases in ituri area. Armed groups became stronger since pacification and in particular areas the context remain unchanged; meaning that armed groups dominate some villages.
Recently small clashes demonstrate the groups willingness to use the force, and mass killings in small extent have occurred in the previous years (16-17).
Therefore, if security situation remain unchanged, the likelihood of a mass killing in DRC is actually high.
The conflict there makes an event a non trivial chance. However so far the fighting has led to small groups of deaths rather than mass killings.
